fish.name: Octopus
fish.fact: Octopuses have blue blood because their blood contains a copper-based protein called hemocyanin, instead of the iron-based hemoglobin found in human blood.

fish.name: Cuttlefish
fish.fact: Cuttlefish can change their color and pattern more dramatically than other cephalopods. They can use color to camouflage, communicate, and attract mates.

fish.name: Anglerfish
fish.fact: It finds food by angling prey in with a light that comes off the front of its head, which acts like a fishing lure. The fishing lure on the anglerfish is called the illicium. The anglerfish lives in the deepest part of the ocean where there is no light.

fish.name: Electric Eel
fish.fact: Electric eels are technically knifefish, not eels. They belong to the Gymnotiformes order, which is closely related to the Siluriformes order, which includes catfish and carp

fish.name: Sea Horse
fish.fact: Male seahorses carry the eggs after mating. The female transfers her eggs to the male's brood pouch, where he fertilizes them and carries them until they hatch.

fish.name: Turtle
fish.fact: Turtles have been around for 200â€“300 million years, which is 140 million years before dinosaurs.
